7

HW3 hint

8

#A3 might give a hint if your #B2 is different from our output!

If you’re on a machine that only stores 4 bytes instead of 8 
bytes (int32 instead of int64), you might get different values 
when very very big multiplication or very very small 
multiplication happens

HW3 errata

●
Notes on the above hints / errata are already updated 
on Canvas (but the content of the questions are all the 
same; you can turn in your ipynb based on either 
download)


●
Going forward, we will consolidate fixes from Ed 
discussions into Canvas / lecture announcements! 


●
We are human and make mistakes; please let us know 
if you catch other issues & we will fix them ASAP!

●

Reshaping

https://twitter.com/UTHealth_BaDS/status/1208133940336300033/photo/1
 

19

Reshaping dataframes: what?

●
Sometimes your data will come to you in a form 
where you either wish the columns were rows, or 
vice versa

20

Reshaping dataframes: why?

●
Sometimes your data will come to you in a form 
where you either wish the columns were rows, or 
vice versa


●
Getting it into the format you want can help you 
do aggregations (e.g. group by, sum), mutations 
(make a new column using old columns), run 
regressions (using x and y as columns), etc.

21

Reshaping: how?

●
When in doubt, Google search for how to convert 
from “long to wide” or “wide to long” with Pandas


29

Reshaping: how?

●
When in doubt, Google search for how to convert 
from “long to wide” or “wide to long” with Pandas

●
Many methods, some fancier (e.g. multiple 
columns at a time)

Long to wide

Wide to long

pivot()

unstack()

long_to_wide()

melt()

stack()

wide_to_long()

Default column names: 

●
“
variable
” contains what used to be the column name (in the list of value_vars)

●
“
value
” is the contents of the cells in the columns within value_vars

●
You can change these column names in the same melt() statement using 
var_name
 and 
value_name
 options

Regression recap

●
We find intercept 
ɑ
 and slope 
β
 by 
minimizing the sum of squared errors 
ε


○

packages that will automatically give us the 
numbers 
ɑ
 and 
β

Today: regression transformations that 
have 
different relationships

72

What is a transformation?

●
x 
→
 f(x)


●
Transformation functions are things like...

○
Squaring

○
Logarithms

○
Exponentiating

○
Adding/subtracting a constant

○
...

73

What is a transformation?

●
x 
→
 f(x)


●
Transformation functions are things like...

○
Squaring: 
if x=5, f(x) = 25

○
Logarithms: 
if x=5, f(x) = [unclear, what base are we using?]

○
Exponentiating

○
Adding/subtracting a constant

○
...

74

Can we use transformations with 
regressions?

●
Original model:
 
y = 
ɑ
 + 
β
x

●
Transformed model: 

○
f(y)
 = 
ɑ
 + 
β
x

○
y = 
ɑ
 + 
β
 * 
f(x)

○
f(y) 
= 
ɑ
 + 
β
 * 
f(x)



75

Can we use transformations with 
regressions?

●
Original model:
 
y = 
ɑ
 + 
β
x

●
Transformed model: 

○
f(y)
 = 
ɑ
 + 
β
x

○
y = 
ɑ
 + 
β
 * 
f(x)

○
f(y) 
= 
ɑ
 + 
β
 * 
f(x)


●
If f() is not linear (e.g. logarithmic, quadratic), 
are these still linear regressions? 

76

琀
琀

Can we use transformations with 
regressions?

●
If f() is not linear (e.g. logarithmic, quadratic), 
are these still linear regressions? YES!



77

Can we use transformations with 
regressions?

●
If f() is not linear (e.g. logarithmic, quadratic), 
are these still linear regressions? YES!

●
Pretend like you are Python. If I tell you to run 
the regression Z ~ X, is this a linear regression?

Can we use transformations with 
regressions?

●
If f() is not linear (e.g. logarithmic, quadratic), 
are these still linear regressions? YES!

●
Pretend like you are Python. If I tell you to run 
the regression Z ~ X, is this a linear regression?

●
Yes! You’d have no idea that Z was secretly Y
2
!

Can we use transformations with 
regressions?

●
If f() is not linear (e.g. logarithmic, quadratic), 
are these still linear regressions? YES!

●
Pretend like you are Python. If I tell you to run 
the regression Z ~ X, is this a linear regression?

●
Yes! You’d have no idea that Z was secretly Y
2
!

●
It doesn't matter whether there’s a (nonlinear) 
relationship among variables: from the perspective 
of the regression, they're just numbers.

Why would we use transformations 
in regressions?

●
Transformations (including non-linear ones) 
are used to 
achieve greater linearity 
in a 
linear regression model


●
Transformations can allow for easier 
interpretability of your model and data

Caution: Heteroskedasticity

●
“Heteroskedasticity” is when the 
variance
 of 
the residuals are unequal

Caution: Heteroskedasticity

●
“Heteroskedasticity” is when the 
variance
 of 
the residuals are unequal


●
This is a problem: OLS regressions have a 
baked-in “constant variance assumption” for 
residuals

○
We shouldn’t use OLS regressions if we 
clearly don’t have constant variance

When does heteroskedasticity occur?

●
It depends on the data.  Some common examples:

a.
In time series: values changing in the same way over 
time 
(X = 1970-2023, Y = mobile phone sales)






Residuals

111

When does heteroskedasticity occur?

●
It depends on the data.  Some common examples:

a.
In time series: values changing in the same way over 
time 
(X = 1970-2023, Y = mobile phone sales)

b.
Massive range in values ($1 vs. $10000000)

(
X=income, Y = food expenditures)




Residuals

https://www.buzzfeed.com/caseyrackham/lucille-bluth-quotes-jessica-walter
 

112

When does heteroskedasticity occur?

●
It depends on the data.  Some common examples:

a.
In time series: values changing in the same way over 
time 
(X = 1970-2023, Y = mobile phone sales)

b.
Massive range in values ($1 vs. $10000000)

(
X=income, Y = food expenditures)


●
In these examples: when X is low, everyone has about the 
same Y value (so variance is around 0). When X is high, 
there are more possible Y values (so variance is higher)




Residuals

https://www.buzzfeed.com/caseyrackham/lucille-bluth-quotes-jessica-walter

●
Use transforms
!

←
 most common
)

○
Square root transform

○
Cube root transform

Moral of the story

●
Make a residual plot to check if your data needs 
to be transformed (e.g., if it looks non-random 
and/or has a fan shape indicating 
heteroskedasticity)


●
Transform your data accordingly before you 
run an OLS regression!!

120

Moral of the story

●
Make a residual plot to check if your data needs 
to be transformed (e.g., if it looks non-random 
and/or has a fan shape indicating 
heteroskedasticity)


●
Transform your data accordingly before you 
run an OLS regression!! 
Do not run a 
regression on heteroskedastic data!

There are so many transformations that you can do! E.g. sqrt, squared, log, etc.

Be careful with interpretations!

●
Transforming your data is often necessary 
for your analysis, but the way you interpret 
the regression (especially the “summarize 
the relationship” step) will 
change
!

Interpretation

y = ɑ + β ln(x)

If x is multiplied by 
e
, we expect a β unit change in y

ln(y) = ɑ + βx

β

Model

Interpretation

Linear

y = ɑ + βx

1 unit change in x is associated with a β unit change in y

Linear-log

y = ɑ + β ln(x)

If x is multiplied by 
e
, we expect a β unit change in y

1% change in x is associated with a 0.01*β unit change in y

Log-linear

ln(y) = ɑ + βx

For a 1 unit change in x, we expect y to be multiplied by e
β

1 unit change in x is associated with a 100*(exp(β)-1)% change in y

Log-log

ln(y) = ɑ + β ln(x)

If x is multiplied by 
e
, we expect y to be multiplied by e
β

1% change in x is associated with a β% change in y (
